subject: ART
title: Advanced Printmaking
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours.
requisite: Two courses (ART 2410 or 2420 or 2430 or ART 3530 or ART 3420) and Jr or Sr
description: Students are introduced to advanced techniques toward the creation of original artwork using print media. Traditional methods in intaglio, relief, lithography and screenprinting are emphasized alongside of additional, contemporary modes of making. There is an expectation that students develop projects that align with personal and conceptual paths of research. Instruction includes demonstrations, lectures, viewing prints, group and individual critiques, discussion of contemporary and historical printmaking, and supervised studio work.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: ART
title: Interior Architecture Evidence-Based Design Studio
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Focuses on the practice of Evidence-Based Design (EBD), basing design decisions on research evidence to create design solutions that are not only creatively inspired but also result in more consistently successful design solutions. Emphasis is on barrier-free design concepts, universal design application, and code compliance. Design investigations include research, programming, analysis, theory, ideation and conceptualization, schematic design, project evaluation, refinement, materials, finishes, detailing, furnishings, lighting, communication graphics, and formal presentation. Topics vary based on current social issues. Students must maintain a computer workstation in the studio.
note: Athens campus fees apply. This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. Add/Drop dates different. To see add/drop dates for this section, click on the course title to view expanded class details.

subject: ART
title: Interior Architecture Supportive Environments Studio
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: This course emphasizes the use of design strategies addressing user's physiological, informational, and social needs to create supportive environmental designs. This includes investigations in how building form, materiality and human factors affect designed space composition. In creating supportive environmental designs, investigations include research, programming, analysis, theory, ideation and conceptualization, schematic design, project evaluation, refinement, materials, finishes, detailing, furnishings, lighting, communication graphics, and formal presentation.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

description: Investigation and application of business procedures, types of business, insurance, liabilities, contractual agreements, and the support materials needed to operate a professional design practice. Professional presentation skills explored.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: ART
title: Construction Documents
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: Art 2600 and two of the following interior architecture studios: Art 2620, 3600, 3620 or 4600
description: This course includes the study and production of construction documents as architectural graphic communications, which present and communicate specific dimensions and materials required to physically construct interior environments. Students engage industry standards, learn to critically evaluate design proposals in terms of construction potentials, critically use professional processes, methods, and techniques, and learn to communicate effectively with these standards.
note: This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. Athens campus fees apply. Add/Drop dates different. subject: ART
title: Advanced Painting and Drawing: Investigative modes; Defining trajectories
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours.
requisite: ART 2710 and 2720 and two 2000-level Studio Art courses

subject: ART
title: Anatomical Drawing and Figure Drawing
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: (JUNIOR or SENIOR) and (BIOS 1030 or BIOS 1300 or BIOS 1710) and (ART 1111 or ART 1121 or ART 1200 or ART 1220)
description: Anatomical Drawing and Figure Drawing is an introduction and overview of the technical aspects of figure drawing. Students use both analogue and digital anatomical illustration practices to explore ways that these techniques can be applied to artmaking as well as to scientific research.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: ART
title: Advanced Photography
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours.
description: This course provides an introduction to view camera operation and the basics of studio lighting. Students build on the fundamental technical skills and conceptual issues of analog black and white photography covered in ART 2810, with a special focus on refining darkroom skills and large scale printing. Through an introduction to its history and contemporary practitioners, students engage in dialogue about the aesthetic and conceptual potentials of film-based photography. In addition to skill building, there is an emphasis on the fundamental questions of why and how artists use these tools within the larger context of contemporary art. Class time is devoted to demonstrations, lab periods, presentations, discussions and critiques.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: ART
title: Studio Art Topics
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours.
requisite: (Jr or Sr) and two 2000-level Studio Art courses
description: Addresses topical/thematic approaches to art-making emphasizing single and multi- (and/or inter-) disciplinarity. Students will research and address topical or media specific concerns via studio and scholarly approaches. Offers experiences in the most current topics/themes in the professional practice of art.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. This course focuses on abstraction in drawing, painting, collage and assemblage. Using mixed media and experimental approaches to traditional media, students will develop a series of 2D and 3D projects. While examining abstract genres and artworks throughout history via lectures, presentations, and discussions, students will generate a body of work with an aim toward uncovering their unique language of marks, compositions, and significance.

subject: ART
title: Studio Art Topics
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours.
requisite: (Jr or Sr) and two 2000-level Studio Art courses
description: Addresses topical/thematic approaches to art-making emphasizing single and multi- (and/or inter-) disciplinarity. Students will research and address topical or media specific concerns via studio and scholarly approaches. Offers experiences in the most current topics/themes in the professional practice of art.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. This course uses three-dimensional aspects of fiber practice, such as patternmaking, sewn forms, and weaving on- and off-loom to explore concepts of softness, permeability, interactivity, and the body. Readings and process-based exploration support students' self-directed project work, which may incorporate or connect with work in external materials and processes.

subject: ART
title: Studio Art Topics
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours.
requisite: (Jr or Sr) and two 2000-level Studio Art courses
description: Addresses topical/thematic approaches to art-making emphasizing single and multi- (and/or inter-) disciplinarity. Students will research and address topical or media specific concerns via studio and scholarly approaches. Offers experiences in the most current topics/themes in the professional practice of art.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. This drawing course focuses on developing perceptual skills, emphasizing accurately rendering the anatomical human figure in proportion using a nude model. The class will reinforce foundational drawing principles, including line, value, shape, texture, and color, while introducing advanced techniques for manipulating spatial illusions, composition, and expressive meaning.  Each drawing topic will be explored through in-class projects with various drawing mediums, and corresponding homework assignments.  Lectures and presentations will provide an understanding of the historical context of figure drawing, focusing on contemporary practices.

subject: ART
title: Studio Art Topics
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours.
requisite: (Jr or Sr) and two 2000-level Studio Art courses
description: Addresses topical/thematic approaches to art-making emphasizing single and multi- (and/or inter-) disciplinarity. Students will research and address topical or media specific concerns via studio and scholarly approaches. Offers experiences in the most current topics/themes in the professional practice of art.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. This course is an introduction to the materials and critical issues of contemporary fiber art, with a particular focus on the 2 D and the 3D. Students explore fiber and textile media and techniques such as stitching, dyeing, and three-dimensional structures through sampling and self-directed projects. Process and material-based work is conducted in an atmosphere of investigation toward hierarchical systems of labor and artistic production. Readings and class discussion contribute to this investigation, focusing on issues essential to the understanding of fiber's role in contemporary art discourse.

subject: ART
title: Museum Fundamentals II - Practicum
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Museum Fundamentals II builds on knowledge acquired in Museum Fundamentals I. Working as a cohort, under the guidance of museum staff, students will collaborate and share responsibilities for researching, planning, designing, interpreting, and installing a cohesive exhibition utilizing various collections located on the Ohio University campus. The course concludes with an exhibition, programming, and opening reception for the public.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: ART
title: Student Design Agency: OU Design Collaborative in the Community
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 8 hours.
description: This course emphasizes incorporating design theory and practice in the applied context of a professional design studio setting. Student designers are responsible for the creation and production of communications solutions for on-campus and off-campus community partners, with an emphasis on partnering with nonprofit organizations and within the Ohio Valley Center for Collaborative Arts.
note: The class will be delivered as a hybrid of in-person instruction and online instruction. The class will meet in-person at the designated meeting time and location. In addition, some class sessions will be delivered online using a course delivery and management system. The instructor will provide a course schedule on or before the first day of class.

retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours.

subject: ART
title: Critique Community
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 16 hours.
requisite: BFA Studio Art major and 3 studio courses at the 3000-4000 level
description:
Critique Community is a workshop for the development of individual studio art practices. Students pursue individual projects of study, research, and production within disciplinary, multi-disciplinary and interdisciplinary frameworks. Students build upon skills initiated in their concentrated areas of study toward a new body of work as their culminating thesis project. In doing so, they explore means, methods, forms and strategies for exhibition or dissemination of the thesis work. 

Ongoing critique experiences with the instructor and peers guide their project's progress throughout the semester. Discussion and readings help students to position their work within the discourse of contemporary practices. Presentation of ideas and concepts both verbally and in written statements accompany studio production.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. Students in the Printmaking concentration should enroll in this section.

subject: ART
title: Interior Architecture Holistic Solutions Studio
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: This course applies both the art and science of design practice by emphasizing using design strategies to address user's physiological, informational, and social needs. This includes investigations in how building form, materiality and human factors affect designed space composition. In creating supportive environmental designs, investigations include research, programming, analysis, theory, ideation and conceptualization, schematic design, project evaluation, refinement, materials, finishes, detailing, furnishings, lighting, communication graphics, and formal presentation.
note: Athens campus fees apply. This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. Add/Drop dates different. To see add/drop dates for this section, click on the course title to view expanded class details.

subject: ART
title: Interior Architecture Holistic Solutions Studio
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: This course applies both the art and science of design practice by emphasizing using design strategies to address user's physiological, informational, and social needs. This includes investigations in how building form, materiality and human factors affect designed space composition. In creating supportive environmental designs, investigations include research, programming, analysis, theory, ideation and conceptualization, schematic design, project evaluation, refinement, materials, finishes, detailing, furnishings, lighting, communication graphics, and formal presentation.
note: Athens campus fees apply. This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. Add/Drop dates different. title: Design Issues & Contemporary Practices: Research, Programming & Thesis Preparation

subject: ART
title: Service Learning in the Visual Arts
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 4 hours.
description: Gives students opportunities to make meaningful connections between artistic and design practice and service. Students may engage in field experiences that involve providing art instruction in an institutional environment or working in collaborative art or design settings. Students will be introduced to the range of issues faced by artists and designers who choose to work in a service capacity.
note: Contact the instructor for in-person meeting requirements for the appropriate location.

subject: ART
title: Interior Architecture VI: Thesis Studio
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: A cap-stone studio course, where students select, develop, and present a complete interior design project with direction and consultation of a faculty advisor. The final work selection, development, and overall character will be approved by designated IA Faculty. Requires the application of interdisciplinary knowledge, synthesized with experienced gained in prior studios and coursework. Thesis includes a final exhibition in a public venue. Student must maintain computer workstation in the design studio.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: ART
title: Art Worlds: Intersections & Modalities
retake: May not be repeated.
description: This course disrupts monolithic conceptions of the "art world" by asking participants to map the various institutions, organizations, and communities making up this ecosystem. Participants consider both practical and philosophical concerns, from capital flow and systems of power to radical economies and community involvement. Special attention is paid to the overlaps, collaborations, and conflicts experienced by entities within their respective art worlds.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: ART
title: Studio Art Topics
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours.
description: Addresses topical/thematic approaches to art-making emphasizing single and multi- (and/or inter-) disciplinarity in a manner that focuses on advanced explorations and self-directed research. Students will research and address topical or media specific concerns via studio and scholarly approaches. Offers experiences in the most current topics/themes in the professional practice of art.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. This course is an experimental and hands-on experiential studio art course that focuses on contemporary digital practices, explorations, and technologies in relation to topics of creative generation, spatial experiences, installation, modes of presentation and creation, and digital and physical fabrication for art productions incorporating the techniques, possibilities, and their presentations in physical or virtual spaces.

resources.content: Course Fee covers equipment/facility use, consumable supplies, and/or other associated costs

subject: ART
title: Studio Art Topics
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours.
description: Addresses topical/thematic approaches to art-making emphasizing single and multi- (and/or inter-) disciplinarity in a manner that focuses on advanced explorations and self-directed research. Students will research and address topical or media specific concerns via studio and scholarly approaches. Offers experiences in the most current topics/themes in the professional practice of art.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. This course uses three-dimensional aspects of fiber practice, such as patternmaking, sewn forms, and weaving on- and off-loom to explore concepts of softness, permeability, interactivity, and the body. Readings and process-based exploration support students' self-directed project work, which may incorporate or connect with work in external materials and processes.

resources.content: Course Fee covers equipment/facility use, consumable supplies, and/or other associated costs

subject: ART
title: Studio Art Topics
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours.
description: Addresses topical/thematic approaches to art-making emphasizing single and multi- (and/or inter-) disciplinarity in a manner that focuses on advanced explorations and self-directed research. Students will research and address topical or media specific concerns via studio and scholarly approaches. Offers experiences in the most current topics/themes in the professional practice of art.
note:
The class will be delivered as a hybrid of in-person instruction and online instruction. The class will meet in-person at the designated meeting time and location. In addition, some class sessions will be delivered online using a course delivery and management system. The instructor will provide a course schedule on or before the first day of class. This course provides a comprehensive study and practice of the methods and
production practices within the area of creative direction. Emphasis will be focused
on leading design teams through the process of developing project proposals,
design systems, and deliverables that address client issues and further their design
practices. Through the application of research, students will thoroughly define
project goals and produce solutions through various media based on project
requirements. Additionally, each student will further their design practice through
the production of new work that is highly conceptual, experimental, and based on
research. Refinement of projects will be accomplished through an emphasis on
critique and iteration.

subject: ART
title: Service Learning in the Visual Arts
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 5 hours.
description: Gives students opportunities to make meaningful connections between studio art and design practice and service. Students may engage in field experiences that involve providing art instruction in an institutional environment or working in collaborative art or design settings. Students will be introduced to the range of issues faced by studio artists and designers who choose to work in a service capacity.
note: Contact the instructor for in-person meeting requirements for the appropriate location.

subject: ART
title: Museum Fundamentals II - Practicum
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Museum Fundamentals II builds on knowledge acquired in Museum Fundamentals I. Working as a cohort, under the guidance of museum staff, students will collaborate and share responsibilities for researching, planning, designing, interpreting, and installing a cohesive exhibition utilizing various collections located on the Ohio University campus. The course concludes with an exhibition, programming, and opening reception for the public.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AST
title: Air Force Missions
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Continuation of AST 1010. Introduces students to opportunities in the Air Force in regards to benefits and career classifications. Introduces students to important concepts of professionalism, leadership, and war (theory/doctrine). Continues to build on military communication skills of briefing and writing.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AST
title: Air Power Today
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: History and development of USAF air power from the beginning of the Cold War to Vietnam.  Changing mission of defense establishment: how air power is employed in military, nonmilitary, and strategic operations. History and development of the USAF air power from the Persian Gulf War to the War on Terrorism.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

description: Review of selected concepts, principles, and theories of management as applied in the Air Force. Continued development of communication and leadership skills.

title: Advanced Field Training

description: Field training experience at various U.S. locations to act as a cadet instructor, assisting officers in the training and evaluating of cadet trainees for their fitness to become cadet officers.

title: Strategy and the Use of Force: American Defense Policymaking
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Cultural immersion, provides a better understanding of cultures around the world.  Organization and case studies in defense policy-making and bureaucratic decision-making and preparation for active duty. Continues communicative skills and techniques of leadership. Examines military law and topics preparing officer candidates for active duty.  Prepares future military officer with tools to understand the world better.
note: Contact the instructor for in-person meeting requirements for the appropriate location.

subject: ASTR
title: Survey of Astronomy
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: General introduction to astronomy, with emphasis on the structure of the universe beyond our solar system.  Topics include historical astronomy, the sun, stars, galaxies, interstellar matter, black holes, the "Big Bang" theory, and the evolution of the universe.  No prereq, but familiarity with basic algebra and geometry is beneficial.
note: This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. Athens campus fees apply. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

resources.body: The University has negotiated a special price for a digital copy of this course's required materials through a program with the publisher. The digital copy of the material is listed as Required for this course. You will receive access to digital copies of the materials on the first day of the class. The cost of the materials will be billed automatically to your student account after the deadline to drop the class. After you register, you will receive more information about this program, including an option to opt out of participation. If you would like print copies of the required materials in addition to or instead of the digital copies that will be automatically provided for you, please refer to the Optional material. If you have already purchased the optional textbook for this course, please contact the IT Service Desk, servicedesk@ohio.edu, to discuss your options. ORC (Ohio Revised Code) 5739.01(B)(12) was added to Ohio law 1/1/2014 and dictates that digital delivery of textbooks is subject to Ohio sales tax. The sale of digital textbooks is subject to a 7% sales tax charge.

subject: ASTR
title: Observational Astronomy Laboratory
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Experience with telescopes and locating stars, planets, and deep-sky objects in the night sky. Also covers major constellations, seasonal variations, lunar cycles, and, when appropriate, eclipses and comets.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: ASTR
title: Fundamentals of Astrophysics
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: PHYS 2052 or (2056 and 2057) and MATH 3300 (Some experience with computer programming is recommended)
description: Physical foundations of astronomical observation and theory.  Specific topics include time and coordinate systems, orbits, celestial mechanics, radiation mechanisms, spectra, telescopes, and instrumentation.  In addition, an introduction to the physical properties of stars, galaxies, and interstellar matter and an overview of cosmological distance measurements and the "hot big bang" model will be covered, along with an introduction to astronomical data analysis.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AT
title: Introduction to Sports Medicine
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Provides an introduction to sports medicine by describing scope of practice, employment settings, and professional regulations of various sports medicine professionals. This course also introduces basic topics related to sports medicine and scientific principles related to illness and injury.
note: Athens campus fees apply. This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: AT
title: Introduction to Athletic Training Clinical Experiences
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 2 hours.
description: Provides direct observation and discussion of athletic training evaluation and interventions in athletic training facilities for undergraduate students considering athletic training as a career.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AT
title: Musculoskeletal Movement in Performing Arts
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: A study of the demands placed on the human body in dance, music, and theater from musculoskeletal perspectives that include anatomy, kinesiology, biomechanics, and healthcare. Scientific research and case studies highlight the musculoskeletal system and performing arts injuries. Creation and delivery of oral presentations are significant media for gaining mastery of the scientific concepts.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

resources.title: Trail Guide to Movement, 2nd edition

requisite: AT 5110 or Masters of Science in Athletic Training (MS8130)
description: Provides students with information on applications and techniques utilized by sports medicine professionals in orthopedic settings and the athletic training room.
note: Students registering for AT 5100 lecture must also register for a AT 5100 lab. Add/Drop dates different. To see add/drop dates for this section, click on the course title to view expanded class details. In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AT
title: Diagnosis and Care of Upper Extremity Pathologies
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Evidence-based practice applications to the pathology, etiology, diagnostic principles, and therapeutic interventions for common musculoskeletal disorders of the upper extremity.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AT

subject: AT
title: Upper Extremity Gross Anatomy
retake: May not be repeated.
description: This course provides a regional approach to the appreciation of upper extremity, thoracic, and cervical spine cadaver anatomy augmented with neurological and radiographic study. This course is a companion laboratory to AT 5110 Diagnosis and Care of Upper Extremity Pathologies.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AT
title: Diagnosis and Care of Head and Cervical Spine Pathologies
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Introduces diagnostic techniques, immediate management, and appropriate medical and therapeutic interventions for head and cervical spine injuries. Topics include concussions, intracranial hemorrhage, skull fracture, eye trauma, and injuries to the nose, face, and ear.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AT
title: Clinical Reasoning 1
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Develops the students' clinical reasoning skills concerning the lower extremity.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AT
title: Manual Therapy in Rehabilitation
retake: May not be repeated.
description: This course focuses on the identification, treatment, and improvement of musculoskeletal conditions through the use of manual therapy and other manual rehabilitative techniques.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. This section is for the Athletic Training Residency Program.

title: Pharmacology in Athletic Training
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Discussion of pharmacology and its implication in athletic training is the focus. Emphasis is on drug classifications and drug mechanisms of action.
note: This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. Athens campus fees apply.

title: Clinical Reasoning 3
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Develops the students' clinical reasoning skills concerning the spine.
note: The class will be delivered as a hybrid of in-person instruction and online instruction. The class will meet in-person at the designated meeting time and location. In addition, some class sessions will be delivered online using a course delivery and management system. The instructor will provide a course schedule on or before the first day of class.

subject: AT
title: Clinical Research in Athletic Training II
retake: May not be repeated.
description: A continuation of the previous course, this course builds on skills required for utilizing scientific literature to inform clinical practice in athletic training. Emphasizes critical appraisal of clinical topics and the mechanics of scientific writing for a capstone project that produces a critically appraised topic manuscript.
note: Athens campus fees apply. This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services.

subject: AT
title: Clinical Immersion in Athletic Training
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 hours.
description: Immersive clinical education internship conducted under the direct supervision of a clinical preceptor.
note: This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. Athens campus fees apply. Add/Drop dates different. To see add/drop dates for this section, click on the course title to view expanded class details.

subject: AT
title: Athletic Training Practicum 2
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Application of knowledge and skills obtained in the classroom to patient care under the direct supervision of a clinical preceptor. Emphasizes clinical decision-making of the lower extremity and acute general medical conditions.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AT
title: Athletic Training Practicum 4
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Application of knowledge and skills obtained in the classroom to patient care under the direct supervision of a clinical preceptor. Emphasis on interprofessional collaboration and board of certification examination preparation.
note: The class will be delivered as a hybrid of in-person instruction and online instruction. The class will meet in-person at the designated meeting time and location. In addition, some class sessions will be delivered online using a course delivery and management system. The instructor will provide a course schedule on or before the first day of class.

subject: AT
title: Evidence-Based Care in Athletic Training II
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Focuses on an integrative approach to the prevention, evaluation, and treatment of lower extremity, lumbar and sacral spine injuries.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. This section is for the Athletic Training Residency Program.

note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AVN
title: Business in Aviation
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: AVN 3900 and (MGT 2000 or MGT 2100) and Sr only
description: This capstone is a study of business aviation operations, management and finance to include corporate, fractional, charter, Fixed Base Operator (FBO), and various aviation business models. Students will apply research methods to actual cases from business partners and function as aviation business consultants. The result will require a synthesis of ideas and suggested solutions presented to the business partners.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: AVN
title: Advanced Aircraft and Flight Crew Operations
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Introduction to advanced flight crew concepts and procedures with emphasis on professional pilot development, safety standardization, and crew resource management (CRM) techniques. The practical portion includes simulated industry-oriented flight training (air carrier instrument approach procedures, interview and training/qualification simulator profiles, and line-oriented Flight Training -- LOFT). Includes lectures and simulator instruction in Simulator/FTD.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. Course taught in Simulator and Conference Room in McFarland Avionics Engineering Center at University Airport.

subject: BA
title: Introduction to the College of Business
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: This course introduces students to the College of Business and the Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) and Bachelor of Sport Management (BSM) programs. Students explore career management and experiential learning while gaining insight into the professional world. Students develop knowledge and experience that benefit their career path in the business industry.
note: If this class is full, a waitlist will be available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Please note the department/school offering this class section will determine the order in which students are enrolled from the waitlist. Your position on the class waitlist does not indicate the order in which you will be added to the class. Contact the department/school offering the course for additional information. In-person/on-site attendance is required. For students who transfer into the College of Business. Must also register for BA2000 Section 100 (1519).

subject: BA
title: Introduction to Business and Ethical Reasoning
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: This course provides an introduction to the world of business by investigating a wide array of issues and phenomena that business executives face while conducting their work.  Overall goals for the course are to introduce the context of business in general, discuss the challenges people face as they try to lead and navigate their organization(s), and to lay a foundation for personal growth and development for students pursuing business-related studies.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. If this class is full, a waitlist will be available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Please note the department/school offering this class section will determine the order in which students are enrolled from the waitlist. Your position on the class waitlist does not indicate the order in which you will be added to the class. Contact the department/school offering the course for additional information. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

resources.body: The University has negotiated a special price for a digital copy of this course's required materials through a program with the publisher. The digital copy of the material is listed as Required for this course. You will receive access to digital copies of the materials on the first day of the class. The cost of the materials will be billed automatically to your student account after the deadline to drop the class. After you register, you will receive more information about this program, including an option to opt out of participation. If you would like print copies of the required materials in addition to or instead of the digital copies that will be automatically provided for you, please refer to the Optional material. If you have already purchased the optional textbook for this course, please contact the IT Service Desk, servicedesk@ohio.edu, to discuss your options. ORC (Ohio Revised Code) 5739.01(B)(12) was added to Ohio law 1/1/2014 and dictates that digital delivery of textbooks is subject to Ohio sales tax. The sale of digital textbooks is subject to a 7% sales tax charge.

subject: BA
title: Career Management Strategies
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: COB and (Soph or Jr or Sr) and BA 1000
description: This course provides students with a structured approach to optimize experiential learning opportunities. Students focus on career management, personal and professional development, self-reflection, skill development, and building professional relationships and networks.

subject: BA
title: Select Leaders I: Leadership Development for Sophomores
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 4 hours.
description: Students are introduced to principle-based leadership.  Students are asked to define their principles and values and identify their leadership style.  Using the Leadership Practices Inventory self-assessment, students are encouraged to focus on the "Model the Way" behavior and are expected  to find their voice by establishing their principles and style while setting an example through personal leadership.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. If this class is full, a waitlist will be available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Please note the department/school offering this class section will determine the order in which students are enrolled from the waitlist. Your position on the class waitlist does not indicate the order in which you will be added to the class. Contact the department/school offering the course for additional information.

subject: BA
title: Business Administration Tutorial
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 15 hours.
description: Individualized tutorial for HTC students only to conduct in depth research on a business topic. First year.
note: Students and tutors should establish a flexible methodology for tutorial meetings that may result in a mix of virtual and face-to-face meetings or may be entirely virtual with synchronous meetings. Contact the instructor for in-person meeting requirements for the appropriate location.

subject: BA
title: Ohio International Consulting Program
bricks: Bridge: Diversity and Practice (BDP), Bridge: Learning and Doing (BLD)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: The OICP experience gives you an opportunity to leverage your existing business skills and develop new ones in a challenging international environment. Student teams develop and implement a strategy for completing their assigned project in a fashion that satisfies the client and meets the course objectives.  This course also provides students with intercultural knowledge and competence. OICP helps students to increase their own cultural self-awareness within worldwide frameworks. Students grow in cultural openness and curiosity while expanding their communication skills.
note: Contact the instructor for in-person meeting requirements for the appropriate location. OICP VIP.

subject: BA
title: Topics in Business Ethics
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 3 hours.
description: This course covers a variety of special topics in business ethics. Course topics vary and may focus on specific business ethics topics such as corporate social responsibility, accounting, finance, marketing, human resource management, leadership, and intellectual property.
note: This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Athens campus fees apply. Add/Drop dates different. To see add/drop dates for this section, click on the course title to view expanded class details.

resources.body: The University has negotiated a special price for a digital copy of this course's required materials through a program with the publisher. The digital copy of the material is listed as Required for this course. You will receive access to digital copies of the materials on the first day of the class. The cost of the materials will be billed automatically to your student account after the deadline to drop the class. After you register, you will receive more information about this program, including an option to opt out of participation. If you would like print copies of the required materials in addition to or instead of the digital copies that will be automatically provided for you, please refer to the Optional material. If you have already purchased the optional textbook for this course, please contact the IT Service Desk, servicedesk@ohio.edu, to discuss your options. ORC (Ohio Revised Code) 5739.01(B)(12) was added to Ohio law 1/1/2014 and dictates that digital delivery of textbooks is subject to Ohio sales tax. The sale of digital textbooks is subject to a 7% sales tax charge.

subject: BA
title: Internship
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 3 hours.
description: This internship course provides structure to a meaningful experiential learning opportunity for students to gain relevant experience in the business industry under the supervision of an on-site supervisor. Students are responsible for securing their own internship experience and complete a minimum of 1 credit hour, which is approximately 70 on-site work hours.
note: Athens campus fees apply. This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. If this class is full, a waitlist will be available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Please note the department/school offering this class section will determine the order in which students are enrolled from the waitlist. Your position on the class waitlist does not indicate the order in which you will be added to the class. Contact the department/school offering the course for additional information. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: BA
title: Select Leaders II: Leadership Development for Juniors
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 4 hours.
description: Students in second year of the program begin to collect various leadership experiences both inside and outside of the program. Their principles are at the core of these experiences. Students at this level understand their leadership style and are learning how to be effective when interacting with different individuals and situations. Using the Covey model, students are Independent and working to achieve Public Victory. Students will focus on the Leadership Practices Inventory behavior Challenge the Process. They are expected to search for areas for improvement in both themselves and their organizations. They are encouraged to experiment by taking on different leadership opportunities. .
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. If this class is full, a waitlist will be available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Please note the department/school offering this class section will determine the order in which students are enrolled from the waitlist. Your position on the class waitlist does not indicate the order in which you will be added to the class. Contact the department/school offering the course for additional information.

subject: BA
title: Emerging Leaders II: Leadership Development
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 4 hours.
description: Emerging Leaders II is designed to provide students with the tools and skills they need to become effective leaders.  Students participate in a series of sessions entitled Speak as Well as You Think, based on the work of John Vautier.  These sessions are designed to improve the speaking and message delivery of leaders.  Students are videotaped and provided one on one feedback regarding their message and delivery of the message.  Students participate in designing news ways of thinking about challenging the process and innovation through a series of sessions around lean thinking, value stream mapping, problem solving, and innovation.  Lastly, students participate in a series of sessions, based on the book by Kouzes and Posner entitled The Leadership Challenge.  Students lead each of the sessions and engage their colleagues in discussions and experiential exercises to more deeply understand and practice the behaviors necessary to be an effective leader.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. If this class is full, a waitlist will be available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Please note the department/school offering this class section will determine the order in which students are enrolled from the waitlist. Your position on the class waitlist does not indicate the order in which you will be added to the class. Contact the department/school offering the course for additional information.

subject: BA
title: Select Leaders III: Leadership Development for Seniors
retake: May be repeated for a maximum of 4 hours.
description: The senior year in the program focuses on establishing a legacy. A key element of the Select Leadership Development Program is servant leadership, which is exemplified during the senior year of the program. Seniors are the leaders of the program and are essential to the growth of the sophomores and juniors. Seniors reflect on their development in the program and share their experiences with younger members. The goal of seniors is to achieve Interdependence in Covey's 7 Habits model. Seniors focus on the Leadership Practices Inventory behavior Enable Others to Act. They recognize potential in younger members and empower them to grow in their leadership.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. If this class is full, a waitlist will be available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Please note the department/school offering this class section will determine the order in which students are enrolled from the waitlist. Your position on the class waitlist does not indicate the order in which you will be added to the class. Contact the department/school offering the course for additional information.

subject: BIOL
title: Principles of Biology
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: Non-science majors and WARNING: no credit for this course if taken after BIOS 1700 or PBIO 1140 or 1150
description: Non-science majors explore living organisms from the cellular to ecosystem levels, using scientific information and laboratory exercises to understand historic discovery and contemporary issues in biology and evolutionary processes. No credit for 1010 if already have credit for BIOS 1700, PBIO 1140 or PBIO 1150.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: BIOS
title: Animal Diversity
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: For nonmajors.  Exploring the importance of animal biodiversity through concepts of biology, reproduction, ecology, and evolution of the animal phyla and symbiotic relationships.
note: A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. In-person/on-site attendance is required.

title: Human Biology I:Basic Principles
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: For nonmajors. Humans as biological organisms: our origins, ecology, and inheritance, and functioning of our body systems.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

resources.title: Human Biology: Concepts and Current Issues
resources.comments: Having a text book is recommended. You do not need to buy the study guide or laboratory manual. A hard copy or online version are both acceptable.  You may also rent the text book cheaply.  Look for a cheap text book online. You can get any old edition starting with the 6th edition and including the 7th and 8th editions.

resources.body: The University has negotiated a special price for a digital copy of this course's required materials through a program with the publisher. The digital copy of the material is listed as Required for this course. You will receive access to digital copies of the materials on the first day of the class. The cost of the materials will be billed automatically to your student account after the deadline to drop the class. After you register, you will receive more information about this program, including an option to opt out of participation. If you would like print copies of the required materials in addition to or instead of the digital copies that will be automatically provided for you, please refer to the Optional material. If you have already purchased the optional textbook for this course, please contact the IT Service Desk, servicedesk@ohio.edu, to discuss your options. ORC (Ohio Revised Code) 5739.01(B)(12) was added to Ohio law 1/1/2014 and dictates that digital delivery of textbooks is subject to Ohio sales tax. The sale of digital textbooks is subject to a 7% sales tax charge.

resources.title:
Anatomy & Physiology: The Unity of Form and Function.
This course participates in Inclusive Access. As such, your University bill will automatically be charged for access to the electronic access package from McGraw-Hill
resources.comments: The Inclusive Access fee will cover access to our McGraw-Hill Connect course. Here you will access the electronic textbook and APR lab program. If you took BIOS 1300 at Ohio University, you should still have access to the Connect course and will not be charged a second time.

subject: BIOS
title: Biological Sciences I: Molecules and Cells
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: C or better in BIOS 1030 or ((ACT 23 or SAT 1130) and Chemistry placement 1510) or (ACT 27 or SAT 1280) or (MATH PL2 and Chemistry placement 1510) and WARNING: No credit for both this course & (always deduct credit for the first course taken): PBIO 1140
description: Cellular and molecular biology. Designed for science majors and preprofessional students. Introduction to the chemistry of life, cell structure and function, and the principles of inheritance. Credit not allowed for both 1700 and PBIO 1140.
note: A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: BIOS
title: Biological Sciences II: Ecology, Evolution, Animal Body Systems
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: C- or better in (BIOS 1700 or PBIO 1140)
description: Animal organ systems. Designed for science majors and preprofessional students. Introduction to multicellular life, organ systems, anatomy, physiology, and animal development; emphasis is on comparative strategies within the animal kingdom.  Ecology and evolutionary biology. Introduction to the principles of evolution, ecology, and behavior.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: BIOS
title: Human Biology II: Essentials of Anatomy and Physiology
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: BIOS 1030 or 1710 and WARNING: No credit if taken after 3010
description: Introduction to functional anatomy of the human body.  Emphasis is on the musculoskeletal system and its control by the nervous system. Students will learn how the skeleton, major muscle groups, and nervous system work together during human behaviors such as posture, locomotion, control of the hands, and respiration.
note: A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Athens campus fees apply. This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services.

subject: BIOS
title: Human Biology II Laboratory: Functional Anatomy
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: BIOS 2030 or concurrent and WARNING: No credit if taken after 3015
description: For nonmajors. Laboratory introduction to the functional human anatomy. Emphasis is on the musculoskeletal and other major organ systems:  nervous, circulatory, respiratory, and gastrointestinal.  Students will explore the major patterns of the musculoskeletal and other organ systems through practical exercises with joint-muscle and tissue organ relationships by using articulated skeletons, surface anatomy, and dissection.
note: A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Athens campus fees apply. This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. subject: BIOS
title: Conservation and Biodiversity
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: WARNING: no credit if taken after BIOS 4810
description: For nonmajors. Introduces the student to the modern field of conservation biology and the role of genetics, ecology, life history, and biogeography in the preservation and maintenance of biodiversity. Case studies of endangered animal and plant species will be highlighted.
note: A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Athens campus fees apply. This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. subject: BIOS
title: Microbes and Humans
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: WARNING: no credit if taken after BIOS 3210 or BIOS 3220
description: For nonmajors. A good introduction to microbiology for allied health fields.  Introduction to the history and life of microorganisms with an emphasis on bacteria and viruses. Discussion of the interaction between humans and microbes including vaccines, antibiotics, biotechnology, immunity, disease transmission, and food spoilage. Overview of infectious diseases affecting human organ systems. Application of concepts through reading on current topics.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

resources.body: This section utilizes open educational resources. There will be no required purchases for textbooks or materials.

subject: BIOS
title: Microbes and Humans, Laboratory
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Microbes and Humans lab focuses on growth, metabolic, and structural characteristics of bacteria and other microbes. Students learn and perform aseptic technique and other standard lab skills that have relevance to controlling microbes, observing and quantifying bacteria in food and water, and demonstrating the presence and role of bacteria in the environment. Special topics also include basics of epidemiology and immunology.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: BIOS
title: Genetics in Human Society
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: WARNING: No credit if taken after BIOS 3100
description: For nonmajors. Basic principles of inheritance in humans. Normal and abnormal chromosome constitutions, gene-protein interrelationships, and factors that cause mutations of genes and chromosomes. Significance of genetics in life of human society.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

resources.title: Human Heredity: Principles and Issues
resources.comments: 10th or 9th edition is also fine.

subject: BIOS
title: Ecology in the 21st Century
bricks: Arch: Natural World (ANW), Pillar: Natural Sciences (PNS)
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: WARNING: no credit if taken after BIOS 3750
description: Introductory study of the natural environment and relations of organisms to one another and their surroundings.  Individual, population, and community and global dynamics are considered in natural and human-influenced environments to improve ecological literacy about how the natural world works.
note: This section is offered online only using an online course delivery and management system. Proctored exams may be required. For directions, refer to OHIO Testing Services at www.ohio.edu/oit/ohio-testing-services. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. Athens campus fees apply.

subject: BIOS
title: Human Anatomy
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: C- or better in (BIOS 171 or (1710 and 1715))
description: Structure and general function of all body systems with emphasis on human musculoskeletal system, and human structure/function relations.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

resources.title: Essential Clinical Anatomy
resources.comments: This book is not required. No textbook is required for BIOS 3010. But this is an optional textbook that aligns with course material. Any version works.

resources.title: There is no required textbook for this course. An optional textbook is listed.

subject: BIOS
title: Human Anatomy Lab
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Hands-on experience through working with human anatomy at the level of tissues, organs, and body systems. Emphasizes a basic knowledge of anatomical terminology and the structural basis of body functions. Lab and small-group exercises are organized around human prosected/plastinated specimens, regional-surface anatomy, and musculoskeletal modeling and sketching assignments. To gain an appreciation of basic tissue properties and relationships, labs include direct experience with dissection.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: BIOS
title: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Comparative study of the anatomy of vertebrates. Structure, function, and evolution of the vertebrate body forms and organ systems are compared. Extensive lab work covers each of the major classes of vertebrates and includes dissection.
note: The class will be delivered as a hybrid of in-person instruction and online instruction. The class will meet in-person at the designated meeting time and location. In addition, some class sessions will be delivered online using a course delivery and management system. The instructor will provide a course schedule on or before the first day of class. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: BIOS
title: Laboratory Genetics
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Experiments in basic bacterial, yeast, and Drosophila molecular genetics.  Experiments include site-directed mutagenesis, yeast 2-hybrid analysis, and transposon mutagenesis in Drosophila.  Recombinant DNA techniques designed to familiarize the student with current laboratory procedures in molecular genetics.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

resources.body: The University has negotiated a special price for a digital copy of this course's required materials through a program with the publisher. The digital copy of the material is listed as Required for this course. You will receive access to digital copies of the materials on the first day of the class. The cost of the materials will be billed automatically to your student account after the deadline to drop the class. After you register, you will receive more information about this program, including an option to opt out of participation. If you would like print copies of the required materials in addition to or instead of the digital copies that will be automatically provided for you, please refer to the Optional material. If you have already purchased the optional textbook for this course, please contact the IT Service Desk, servicedesk@ohio.edu, to discuss your options. ORC (Ohio Revised Code) 5739.01(B)(12) was added to Ohio law 1/1/2014 and dictates that digital delivery of textbooks is subject to Ohio sales tax. The sale of digital textbooks is subject to a 7% sales tax charge.

title: Animal Ecology
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.

subject: BIOS
title: Biological Pharmacology
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: SR and (C or better in BIOS 3430 OR BIOS 3450 or concurrent) and (C or better in CHEM 3010 OR 3060 or concurrent)
description: An over-arching synthesis of concepts already learned in cell biology, genetics, physiology and chemistry are applied to the biological principles of drug action. Designed as a capstone experience for students in the sciences, especially the biological sciences. Covers the pathophysiology and therapeutic uses of drugs, for certain human diseases (e.g., heart failure, diabetes, Parkinson's disease, and infectious diseases). A select group of the most commonly prescribed drugs are discussed in terms of their cellular mechanisms of action and how drug actions alter disease states. After successfully completing the learning activities students are better prepared for biomedical careers after graduation. Toxicology and medicinal chemistry of various drug classes are not discussed.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

Approximate Price: $75.00. Required. Additional Comment(s): The textbook is available as an electronic resource through Alden, you can use the resource no charge while you are on the OU campus network or logged into Alice with your OU credentials. if you want to buy a print copy, please get the 9th or 10th edition.

title: Pathogenic Bacteriology
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: C- or better in (BIOS 3220 and BIOS 3225) and WARNING: No credit if taken after BIOS 4230 or 5230
description: A molecular approach is used to discuss bacterial pathogenesis and disease manifestations. Topics include aspects of immunity and pathogen control.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: BIOS
title: Mechanisms of Gene Regulation
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: C- or better in BIOS 3100 and (Jr or Sr)
description: Class is intended for upper-level undergraduates and graduate students.  An in-depth discussion of the molecular events that regulate eukaryotic gene expression.  Topics also include gene regulation during differentiation and development, aberrant transcription and disease, generation and utility of transgenic animals, and genomics-based analysis of gene expression.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: BIOS
title: Biological Chemistry
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: (C- or better in CHEM 3010 or 3050) and (C- or better in BIOS 1700 and BIOS 1710)
description: Biological Chemistry covers structure/function of proteins, nucleotides, lipids, and carbohydrates. Other topics covered include principles of enzyme kinetics, chemical/physical, and functional properties of biological membranes, and DNA synthesis, transcription and translation. Finally, biochemistry of energy and nucleotide metabolism and mechanisms of metabolic regulation are also covered.

description: Mammals; their origin, evolution and adaptations, geographical distribution, ecology, and systematics. Emphasis on local fauna.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

resources.authors: John D. Harder, Guy N. Cameron
resources.title: Mammals of Ohio

subject: BIOS
title: Animal Conservation Biology
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: 20 hours in BIOS and Sr only
description: The roles of population genetics, population and community ecology, biogeography, systematics, and paleobiology in the study of biodiversity, design of nature reserves, and the recovery of endangered species. Discussion of extinction as a process, the effects of human-induced habitat degradation on loss of species diversity, and the role of reserves in protection of species.
note: A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting. In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: BIOS
title: Fundamentals of Immunology
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
requisite: C- or better in BIOS 3220 and BIOS 3225
description: This course introduces the components of the immune system and examines the innate and adaptive immune responses to a variety of pathogens.  Additional topics include lymphocyte development, immunization, and experimental techniques.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: BIOS
title: Senior Research and Thesis
retake: May be retaken two times excluding withdrawals, but only last course taken counts.
description: Independent research and thesis under the supervision of a faculty member. Requires students already actively involved in a research project to present their research findings, both orally and in written thesis format. It is intended for students who are not pursuing a degree in Biological Sciences with honors. Students should enroll in the semester the research will be completed and thesis presented.
note: Contact the instructor for in-person meeting requirements for the appropriate location.

description: Independent departmental honors research thesis under supervision of staff member. Student should enroll semester he or she expects to complete thesis. Registration with director of departmental honors program is required.
note: Contact the instructor for in-person meeting requirements for the appropriate location.

subject: BIOS
title: Human Anatomy
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Provides basic and advanced training in body structure/function relations for students who have only limited undergraduate exposure to Human Anatomy.  Beyond the basic course requirements, graduate students will be assigned an additional, in-depth survey or research paper on an advanced topic in functional human anatomy.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this class section. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

resources.title: Essential Clinical Anatomy
resources.comments: This book is not required. No textbook is required for BIOS 3010. But this is an optional textbook that aligns with course material. Any version works.

resources.title: There is no required textbook for this course. An optional textbook is listed.

subject: BIOS
title: Human Anatomy
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Provides basic and advanced training in body structure/function relations for students who have only limited undergraduate exposure to Human Anatomy.  Beyond the basic course requirements, graduate students will be assigned an additional, in-depth survey or research paper on an advanced topic in functional human anatomy.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required. A waitlist is available for this section, however, you should not use the "swap" feature when adding this section to a waitlist. Please see www.ohio.edu/registrar/waitlisting-faq for more information about waitlisting.

subject: BIOS
title: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Comparative study of the anatomy of vertebrates. Structure, function, and evolution of the vertebrate body forms and organ systems are compared. Extensive lab work covers each of the major classes of vertebrates and includes dissection.
note: The class will be delivered as a hybrid of in-person instruction and online instruction. The class will meet in-person at the designated meeting time and location. In addition, some class sessions will be delivered online using a course delivery and management system. The instructor will provide a course schedule on or before the first day of class.

resources.body: There is no required textbook for the Lecture portion of this class. Individual materials as assigned

subject: BIOS
title: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy
retake: May not be repeated.
description: Comparative study of the anatomy of vertebrates. Structure, function, and evolution of the vertebrate body forms and organ systems are compared. Extensive lab work covers each of the major classes of vertebrates and includes dissection.
note: In-person/on-site attendance is required.

subject: BIOS
title: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy
